trans-unit.source: Describes the functions to use in an Azure Resource Manager template to retrieve values, format strings and retrieve deployment information.
trans-unit.target: Describes the functions to use in an Azure Resource Manager template to retrieve values, format strings and retrieve deployment information.

trans-unit.source: This topic describes all of the functions you can use in an Azure Resource Manager template.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes all of the functions you can use in an Azure Resource Manager template.

trans-unit.source: Returns the sum of the two provided integers.
trans-unit.target: Returns the sum of the two provided integers.

trans-unit.source: Returns the base64 representation of the input string.
trans-unit.target: Returns the base64 representation of the input string.

trans-unit.target: The string value to return as a base64 representation.

trans-unit.source: Combines multiple string values and returns the resulting string value.

trans-unit.source: Returns the integer division of the two provided integers.
trans-unit.target: Returns the integer division of the two provided integers.

trans-unit.source: Number which is used to divide, has to be different from 0.
trans-unit.target: Number which is used to divide, has to be different from 0.

trans-unit.source: Returns the number of elements in an array.
trans-unit.target: Returns the number of elements in an array.

trans-unit.source: Typically, used to specify the number of iterations when creating resources.
trans-unit.target: Typically, used to specify the number of iterations when creating resources.

trans-unit.source: For an example of using this function, see <linkText>Create multiple instances of resources in Azure Resource Manager</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Returns the keys of a storage account.
trans-unit.target: Returns the keys of a storage account.

trans-unit.source: The resourceId can be specified by using the resourceId function or by using the format providerNamespace/resourceType/resourceName.
trans-unit.target: The resourceId can be specified by using the resourceId function or by using the format providerNamespace/resourceType/resourceName.

trans-unit.source: You can use the function to get the primaryKey and secondaryKey.
trans-unit.target: You can use the function to get the primaryKey and secondaryKey.

trans-unit.source: Unique identifier of a storage account.
trans-unit.target: Unique identifier of a storage account.

trans-unit.source: API version of resource runtime state.
trans-unit.target: API version of resource runtime state.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to return the keys from a storage account in the outputs section.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to return the keys from a storage account in the outputs section.

trans-unit.source: Returns the remainder of the integer division using the two provided integers.
trans-unit.target: Returns the remainder of the integer division using the two provided integers.

trans-unit.source: Number which is used to divide, has to be different from 0.
trans-unit.target: Number which is used to divide, has to be different from 0.

trans-unit.source: Returns the multiplication of the two provided integers.
trans-unit.target: Returns the multiplication of the two provided integers.

trans-unit.source: Returns a right-aligned string by adding characters to the left until reaching the total specified length.
trans-unit.target: Returns a right-aligned string by adding characters to the left until reaching the total specified length.

trans-unit.source: The total number of characters in the returned string.
trans-unit.target: The total number of characters in the returned string.

trans-unit.source: The character to use for left-padding until the total length is reached.
trans-unit.target: The character to use for left-padding until the total length is reached.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to pad the user-provided parameter value by adding the zero character until the string reaches 10 characters.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to pad the user-provided parameter value by adding the zero character until the string reaches 10 characters.

trans-unit.source: If the original parameter value is longer than 10 characters, no characters are added.
trans-unit.target: If the original parameter value is longer than 10 characters, no characters are added.

trans-unit.source: The specified parameter name must be defined in the parameters section of the template.
trans-unit.target: The specified parameter name must be defined in the parameters section of the template.

trans-unit.target: The name of the parameter to return.

trans-unit.source: Return information about a resource provider and its supported resource types.
trans-unit.target: Return information about a resource provider and its supported resource types.

trans-unit.source: If not type is provided, all of the supported types are returned.
trans-unit.target: If not type is provided, all of the supported types are returned.

trans-unit.target: The type of resource within the specified namespace.

trans-unit.target: Each supported type is returned in the following format:

trans-unit.source: Enables an expression to derive its value from another resource's runtime state.
trans-unit.target: Enables an expression to derive its value from another resource's runtime state.

trans-unit.source: Name or the unique identifier of a resource.
trans-unit.target: Name or the unique identifier of a resource.

trans-unit.source: API version of resource runtime state.
trans-unit.target: API version of resource runtime state.

trans-unit.source: Parameter should be used if resource is not provisioned within same template.
trans-unit.target: Parameter should be used if resource is not provisioned within same template.

trans-unit.source: The reference function derives its value from a runtime state, and therefore cannot be used in the variables section.
trans-unit.target: The reference function derives its value from a runtime state, and therefore cannot be used in the variables section.

trans-unit.source: It can be used in outputs section of a template.
trans-unit.target: It can be used in outputs section of a template.

trans-unit.source: By using the reference expression, you implicitly declare that one resource depends on another resource if the referenced resource is provisioned within same template.
trans-unit.target: By using the reference expression, you implicitly declare that one resource depends on another resource if the referenced resource is provisioned within same template.

trans-unit.source: You do not need to also use the dependsOn property.
trans-unit.target: You do not need to also use the dependsOn property.

trans-unit.source: The expression is not evaluated until the referenced resource has completed deployment.
trans-unit.target: The expression is not evaluated until the referenced resource has completed deployment.

trans-unit.source: Returns a new string with all instances of one character in the specified string replaced by another character.
trans-unit.target: Returns a new string with all instances of one character in the specified string replaced by another character.

trans-unit.source: The string that will have all instances of one character replaced by another character.
trans-unit.target: The string that will have all instances of one character replaced by another character.

trans-unit.source: The character to be removed from the original string.
trans-unit.target: The character to be removed from the original string.

trans-unit.source: The character to add in place of the removed character.
trans-unit.target: The character to add in place of the removed character.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to remove all dashes from the user-provided string.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to remove all dashes from the user-provided string.

trans-unit.source: Returns the unique identifier of a resource.
trans-unit.target: Returns the unique identifier of a resource.

trans-unit.source: You use this function when the resource name is ambiguous or not provisioned within the same template.
trans-unit.target: You use this function when the resource name is ambiguous or not provisioned within the same template.

trans-unit.source: The identifier is returned in the following format:
trans-unit.target: The identifier is returned in the following format:

trans-unit.source: Default value is current resource group.
trans-unit.target: Default value is current resource group.

trans-unit.source: Specify this value when you retrieving a resource in another resource group.
trans-unit.target: Specify this value when you retrieving a resource in another resource group.

trans-unit.source: Type of resource including resource provider namespace.
trans-unit.target: Type of resource including resource provider namespace.

trans-unit.source: Next resource name segment if resource is nested.
trans-unit.target: Next resource name segment if resource is nested.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to retrieve the resource ids for a web site and a database.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to retrieve the resource ids for a web site and a database.

trans-unit.source: The web site exists in a resource group named myWebsitesGroup and the database exists in the current resource group for this template.
trans-unit.target: The web site exists in a resource group named myWebsitesGroup and the database exists in the current resource group for this template.

trans-unit.source: Often, you need to use this function when using a storage account or virtual network in an alternate resource group.
trans-unit.target: Often, you need to use this function when using a storage account or virtual network in an alternate resource group.

trans-unit.source: The storage account or virtual network may be used across multiple resource groups; therefore, you do not want to delete them when deleting a single resource group.
trans-unit.target: The storage account or virtual network may be used across multiple resource groups; therefore, you do not want to delete them when deleting a single resource group.
